name: 10 Average Questions about The Spanish Inquisition

questions.text: King Ferdinand and his wife, Isabella of Castille, were the sovereigns of Spain during the Inquisition. Which man, who was also Isabella's confessor, convinced her to revive the Inquisition in a specifically Spanish form?
questions.explanation:
Thomas of Torquemada.

	The Inquisition was a religious court that punished people who were convicted of heresy, and the people who questioned the suspected heretics were called Inquisitors. When people were arrested to be questioned, it was called "being put to the question" - in other words, tortured.

questions.text: What kinds of people did the Spanish Inquisition tend to regard with particular suspicion?
options: Those who appeared to question the authority of the Church
questions.explanation:
All of these.

	Both Ferdinand and Isabella were "devout" - or rather, utterly fanatical. They not only encouraged the Spanish Inquisition, but in 1492 they also expelled all "Moors" (that is, Muslims) and Jews from Spain unless they converted to Catholicism. Converts were closely watched by the Inquisition, which suspected that some were still secret Muslims or Jews. To question the authority of the Church was a form of heresy and often resulted in prolonged spells in the Inquisition's torture-chambers.

questions.text: People that were arrested for questioning were tortured until they confessed to being heretics. Which of the following torture methods was NOT used?
questions.explanation:
All of these were used.

	By using these gruesome methods of torture the Inquisition was able to claim, hypocritcally, that it did not commit 'bloodshed'.

questions.text: A wife was allowed to testify against her husband, but if she gave evidence in favor of him, it would be rejected.
questions.explanation:
True.

	Even more unfair than this was that if two people testified in favor of someone who was accused, the evidence was rejected, but if only one person testified against him, the evidence was usually accepted.

questions.text: A witness could say whatever he wanted to say about the prisoner.
questions.explanation:
False.

	If a witness did not say what the Inquisitors wanted him to, *he* could be put under torture.

questions.text: If a person was convicted of heresy, what happened to his property?
options: The heretic's family got to keep all of his property
The heretic had to pay a special monthly "heresy tax" on his property
The heretic got to keep some of his property
questions.explanation:
It was confiscated completely.

	The Inquisitors got to keep a portion of the land, and the rest become the property of Pope Innocent VIII, who originally came up with the idea of an Inquisition.

questions.text: What was the penalty for heresy?
questions.correct: Burning at the stake or a very heavy fine
questions.explanation:
Burning at the stake or a very heavy fine.

	Disemboweling was not introduced until the time of Phillip II.

questions.text: If a man swore profanely, what was his punishment?
questions.correct: He would not be permitted to attend mass
questions.explanation:
He would not be permitted to attend mass.

	However, if a priest swore profanely, he would be fined, but the public would not hear about it.

questions.text: Why did Isabella and Ferdinand instigate the Inquisition in the first place?
questions.correct: They wanted to eradicate Islam, Judaism and heresy from Spain
options: Isabella's confessor blackmailed them into doing it
Pope Innocent VIII made them do it
questions.explanation:
They wanted to eradicate Islam, Judaism and heresy from Spain.

	They thought that if everyone in Spain was the same religion, they would become united. However, it is believed that Ferdinand and Torquemada wanted an Inquisition because they would accumulate the property of the "heretics".

questions.text: When was the Spanish Inquisition established?
questions.explanation:
1478.

	As soon as Isabella and Ferdinand became Spain's sovereigns, they set up the Inquisition. Thank you for playing my quiz, and please rate it.
